Chapter 12: Contemplating Suffering, Contemplating the Absence of Self in Suffering. Next, suffering has no intrinsic nature, and the emptiness that opposes it is refuted in order to prevent fixation, so this chapter arises.
An outsider says:
In the ultimate truth, there are these aggregates.
Why is it so?
Because of suffering.
If this does not exist, then there is no suffering, like a second head.
If the aggregates are suffering, as stated in the sÅ«tra:
Suffering, origination, and also the world, the seen and that which exists.
For this reason, in the ultimate truth, there are these aggregates.
The treatise states:
False discrimination is not so with regard to suffering.
As stated in the verse:
Some wish to attain suffering, created by oneself or by another,
Together, they are not produced without a cause, and their fruits are all unreasonable.
The explanation says:
In the ultimate truth, various immeasurable rational investigations are all unreasonable.
How is it investigated that suffering is not self-produced?
As a verse says:
If suffering is produced by oneself, then it does not arise from conditions.
The explanation says:
Because it is produced by oneself, it does not rely on causes and conditions.
Therefore, suffering arises from conditions, and this meaning does not exist.
But that is unreasonable, and one still wishes to attain it.
What does this mean?
It means arising from conditions.
As a verse says:
The future aggregates arise due to the present aggregates as a cause.
The explanation says:
In the ultimate truth, the continuity of aggregates is called Devadatta, but Devadatta is not produced by Devadatta himself.
Why is it so?
Because it arises from conditions.
It is just like a single existence, where the future aggregates arise due to the present aggregates as a cause. The meaning is exactly like this.
Next, the VÄtsÄ«putrÄ«yas say:
Although the aggregates of faculties such as the body are different, the self is not different. It abides everywhere and is also the agent. It creates this suffering, so it is self-created.
If it is said that the formations are impermanent, arising and ceasing in each moment, this statement has a fault.
What fault is incurred?
The suffering that arises simultaneously with the mind in each moment of the mind is not created by that suffering in that moment, so it is not self-created nor created by another.
Why is this?
It is not reasonable for the results of actions done by another to be experienced by oneself.
If you wish to have it created by another, then it contradicts your own tenet.
The treatise states:
Here we establish a logical argument. Your statement that the person is the agent is not reasonable.
Why is this?
Because it is permanent, like space.
Because of the logical argument of permanence, we know it is not an agent.
The inherent nature of the person as an agent is refuted, due to the fault in the thesis.
Furthermore, if you definitely think that the self creates this suffering, then it does not arise from conditions, and there is this fault.
What is the meaning of this?
In our doctrine, we call suffering the self. The meaning is like this.
Furthermore, if you say that the action done by a man is done by himself, and not done by others relying on other conditions, this is not so.
Why is it so?
Because suffering is done by the self relying on innumerable causes, it should be known like this.
Just as dry grass and cow dung, etc., are conditions for fire, the meaning is exactly like this.
Furthermore, the suffering of Devadatta is not created by Devadatta's self.
Why is it so?
Because of suffering, like the suffering of Yajna.
You said before:
If the momentary conditioned factors, etc., have no separate creator, then the action done is done by the self.
Now I will answer you:
In the ultimate truth, suffering cannot be spoken of, therefore I have no fault.
In conventional truth, characteristics continue in a causal series without distinction. The world universally sees and speaks in this way.

Just as it is said that the lamp comes from there, and that mango tree was planted by me, so it is here as well. The characteristics that exist later continue with those characteristics of previous thoughts, and cause and effect are not distinguished.

The thought with characteristics that existed previously is called self-made in this moment. Due to the wholesome or unwholesome karma accumulated by the thought of the previous moment, when that karma ceases, it becomes the cause for what follows.

Just as the flame of a lamp becomes the cause for what follows, so it is in this way, continuing in a causal series until the result is obtained. Therefore, it is not the case that one does not act and yet obtains [the result], nor that having acted, it is lost and ceases to exist.
If you think that the dharmas of the moments of existence do not receive the later results of the karma accumulated previously,
why is it so?
Because they are different, just like those in a different causal series.
This is not so. As a verse says:
The dharmas of dependent arising in various places are not identical to those conditions,
It is also not different from those conditions, not permanent, and not annihilated.
The explanation says:
The doctrine of self is like this.
What you establish as a reason for difference is not established.
Why is it so?
Because the karma transmitted by the momentary mind of the past, not yet having arisen as an antidote, continues to produce results, due to the superiority of its function.
For example, by soaking a madan flower in lac dye and planting it, later when the flower has the color of lac dye, it does not contradict worldly truth.
Furthermore, the one who speaks of the existence of a person says:
On one side there is the performance of karma, on the other side there is the experience of results, without the above faults.
The treatise says:
That one side does not perform but obtains, and this one side has already performed and lost, because the side that performs karma never obtains results, there is this fault.
The outsider says:
I am one, therefore there is no fault.
How do you know it is one?
Because it corresponds to the number one.
The treatise says:
I am associated with a single number, but this is not the case.
Why is it so?
Because it exists, like a single number.
For this reason, suffering is not self-created, nor is it created by another.
What does this mean?
As a verse says:
If the later aggregates are different from the previous, and the later aggregates are different from the previous ones,
then these aggregates arise from those aggregates, and it can be said that suffering is created by another.
The commentary says:
If a person wishes to attain that suffering is created by another, the substance of the dharma is not established, and the proposition has an error.
But in reality it is not so.
How is it not so?
Here a proof is established: in the ultimate truth, the later aggregates of Devadatta are not another in relation to the previous aggregates.
Why is it so?
Because they are the aggregates of Devadatta, like the substance of the later self-aggregates.
Moreover, because the substance of that suffering is not separate in the continuum, the proposition and example should be understood as before.
Next, the one who grasps at the existence of a person makes this statement:
The result of karma created by others is experienced by oneself.
This is not reasonable.
Why is it so?
Because the distinctions of the various states are all created by people, it is called self-created suffering and also called created by others.
The two schools' established positions do not have this fault.
The treatise states:
You only have this statement, which is also unreasonable.
As a verse says:
If a person creates their own suffering, apart from suffering there is no separate person;
What kind of person is it that says a person creates their own suffering?
The commentary states:
What kind of suffering is it?
It refers to the characteristics of the five aggregates.
Apart from the aggregates of suffering, there is no separate person. How can it be said that a person creates suffering?
Furthermore, if you insist on saying that a person is neither the same as nor different from the five aggregates, this is unreasonable.
Why is it so?
It is only in the five aggregates that the name Devadatta is given, and no person can be found, because it arises from conditions, like a vase and so forth.
In this way, in the ultimate truth, that person is not established. Since the person is not established, there is no one who experiences suffering.
Next, if suffering is created by another person,
this is not reasonable. As a verse says:
If the suffering created by another person is given to this person,
apart from suffering, how can there be another person, and say that suffering is created by another?
The explanation says:
Apart from suffering, there is no person, because this has been refuted earlier.
As for the proof that the person has a separate essence, because there is no valid cognition,
in this way, self-created suffering cannot be found. The previously established reasoning has already made the ignorant understand.
Therefore, a verse says:
If self-creation is not established, where can there be creation by another?
If the suffering created by another person, that is still self-created.
The explanation says:
There is no self-created suffering that can be pointed to and said to be created by another. This statement is not reasonable.
It is not like the case of definite retributive karma in a separate continuum, where it is said that others create it.
Therefore, the verse says, Where is there any creation by another? The meaning of the statement is like this.
You say that there is a difference in states but no difference in the person. This is false speech.
For this reason, whether suffering is created by oneself or by another, both are not correct.
Furthermore, a Nirgrantha said:
Because a person creates suffering, suffering is created by oneself.
Yet suffering is not the person itself, so it is called created by another.
Therefore, both the doors of self-creation and other-creation are established.
The treatise verse states:
Self-creation of suffering is not correct.
The explanation says:
No person creates suffering. This meaning is like this.
Because suffering has no intrinsic nature, and the person has no substance.
If it is said that the essence of suffering is the person, the meaning is also incorrect.
Why is it so?
The verse states:
Suffering does not return to create suffering.
The commentary states:
As previously stated in the verse, If suffering is self-created, then it does not arise from conditions.
These two lines are as previously refuted, with the same meaning.
Moreover, if suffering creates suffering again, then the effect creates the effect again, and suffering arises by itself without depending on causes and conditions.
These two kinds are not seen in the world.
You previously said that suffering is not the person, and this person creates suffering, calling it created by another. This statement is not good.
As stated in the verse:
If suffering is created by another.
The commentary states:
The outsider intends to take the person as another, but this person has no substance and cannot create suffering.
Why is it not created?
Because it is empty.
If empty, then it is nothing. How can it give rise to creation?
The wise do not accept that which arises without substance.
Therefore, the verse states:
Without another, who creates suffering?
The commentary states:
There is no such meaning of other. The meaning of the words is like this.
For this reason, self-making and other-making are both unreasonable.
The joint-maker says:
Since the two make suffering, there is no fault.
In order to refute this, the Ä€cÄrya's verse says:
If each one makes it, one can say the two make suffering.
The explanation says:
Each one does not make it, as has already been refuted.
Suffering is neither self-made nor made by another. Therefore your statement that the two make suffering, this meaning is unreasonable.
It is also not without a cause.
Why is it so?
This grasping at causelessness has already been refuted in the chapter on non-arising.
A verse in this chapter says:
Self, other, and both do not make it. How can there be suffering without a cause?
The explanation says:
What has been said in this chapter so far, if suffering is without a cause, then it also has no suffering.
There is no such meaning of suffering having a cause.
In the ultimate truth, suffering cannot be found. The meaning of the statement is like this.
In this way, various investigations show that suffering has no essence.
In the beginning of the outsider's chapter, it was said that the aggregates exist because suffering is their cause. In the ultimate truth, this assertion is not established.
As a verse says:
Not only is the observation of suffering not established, the four meanings are not established;
The external phenomena also lack the four.
The commentary says:
As explained by the previous reasoning, the investigation of external form and so forth also lacks this meaning.
How is form not self-made?
Why is it so?
Because existence and non-existence as causes are not reasonable, as explained before.
Moreover, because it arises from conditions, the essence of a sprout is not called self-made.
If it is said that what is made from the elements is called other-made, this is not reasonable.
Why is it not reasonable?
The elements are not called other with respect to form.
Why is it so?
Because it is external, like the substance of form itself.
Moreover, because it refutes real existence, form has no substance, and the opponent's argument is not established.
It is also not produced by both, because each individually is not established.
It is also not without a cause.
Why is this?
Because this view of causelessness has already been refuted earlier.
Sound and so forth should also be refuted in the same way.
Therefore, the reason stated at the beginning of the chapter, because of suffering, is not established due to having faults.
In this chapter, in order to demonstrate that suffering is the meaning of emptiness, it is therefore established.
As stated in the Perfection of Wisdom Sutra, the Buddha told the bodhisattva Supreme Courage:
Good man!
Form is neither suffering nor happiness, and so are feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness, neither suffering nor happiness.
If form, feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness are neither suffering nor happiness, this is called the perfection of wisdom.
Also, as stated in the Brahma King's Question Sutra:
What is called the noble truth?
Whether it is suffering, accumulation, cessation, or path, it is not called a noble truth.
When suffering and so forth do not arise, it is called a noble truth.
And so on.

Here, an outsider quotes the sÅ«tra to establish the meaning, as stated in the verse:

The commentary states:

The treatise states:
Here, a logical argument is presented: in the ultimate truth, all internal phenomena are empty.
Why is this?
Because they are robbed of their nature, like an illusory person.
The opponent says:
The thesis and reason are indistinguishable.
You say that in the ultimate truth, all phenomena are empty, which is non-existent;
The robbed of their nature is also non-existent.
Because the reason is lacking, the thesis is not established, because there is an error.
The treatise states in verse:

The commentary states:

If so, since this is non-existent, what is there that can be called robbery?
Because it has no substance, it is like a rabbit's horns.
Therefore, the two phrases false and robbery are not meaningless.
What other meaning is there?
Distinguishing objects, their own nature is empty, this is the meaning of false, not existing as it is, like a shadow.
This is the meaning of robbery. The reason and the thesis are not the same. Therefore, I do not have the fault of lacking a reason in my thesis.
Because there are no two faults, the intended meaning is established.

Moreover, as for the meaning of robbery, the Buddha BhagavÄn has completely eradicated the afflictive hindrances and the cognitive hindrances, leaving nothing remaining. Therefore, he speaks like this.
As a verse says:
The BhagavÄn speaks of this in order to reveal the meaning of emptiness.
The commentary says:
As for the meaning of robbery, it is no different from emptiness. It is like saying where there is smoke, there is fire.
The opponent says:
False speech is not meaningless.
What is the meaning of this?
It means that the TathÄgata does not say that all dharmas are without self.
If so, then how does he speak false speech?
As a verse says:
Because we see the transformation of phenomena, all dharmas are without self-nature.
The commentary says:
What does this verse mean?
It means that because we see the transformation of phenomena, we know that all dharmas are without substance.
How are they without substance?
Because they are not permanent.
The BhagavÄn said that those who speak falsely are like this in principle.
Moreover, as a verse says:
Having substance is not non-having.
The commentary says:
What is called having?
Because the self-nature exists.
According to your principle, all dharmas are without substance, but this is not so.
The verse says:
Because all dharmas are empty.
The commentary says:
Because all dharmas are without self and what belongs to self, your meaning is like this. Therefore, you should believe that all dharmas have substance.
If it is not like this, the verse says:
If the self-nature does not exist, what dharma transforms?
The commentary says:
Because we directly perceive that this substance undergoes transformation, therefore we definitely know that there is a dharma of transformation.
Here we establish a logical argument: in the ultimate truth, all dharmas have substance.
Why is this?
Because the substance undergoes transformation.
If this were without substance, then there would be no transformation, like the child of a barren woman.
Because there is the transformation of substance, referring to the internal sense bases and so forth, therefore in the ultimate truth, dharmas have their own substance.
The treatise's verse states:
If a dharma has its own substance, how can it undergo transformation?
The commentary explains:
It is not reasonable for a dharma that has its own substance to undergo transformation.
Why is this?
Because that which has its own substance cannot be destroyed.

But now we directly perceive that substance undergoes transformation. Therefore we should know that the substance of transformation cannot be separated from that which lacks its own substance. The reason you have established contradicts itself.
Some say that the meaning of false dharmas is that those who do not see the non-self-nature of dharmas as it really is are said to expound the meaning of no-self.
Why is this?
The term self-nature is precisely the name for self.
Seeing the transformation of dharmas is said to be the transformation and destruction of all dharmas.
Therefore, the speaker of false words is not separate from the teaching of no-self.
This false speech is said to be the teaching of no-self, not the teaching of emptiness.

Therefore, before the noble path arises and the mountain of the view of self has not collapsed, the light and shadow of self and what belongs to self appear in regard to internal and external dharmas;
When the noble path arises, one no longer discriminates between self and what belongs to self in regard to these dharmas.
If it is said that dharmas have no self-nature, like the self grasped by non-Buddhists, this self has no substance.
Establishing this meaning would be establishing what I have already established.
Such a reason establishes no-self, but does not establish emptiness or the absence of self-nature.
The treatise states:
You who discriminate that dharmas have no substance, say that it is like the horns of a rabbit, and that substance is like this, therefore giving rise to fear.
It is like a small child who sees his own shadow at night, thinking it is a non-human, and cries out in fright.
You are also like this.
As you say, the non-Buddhists grasp at a self, establishing this non-self then becomes what I have established.
Now listen carefully, if you use false words to establish the absence of self, and the self grasped at by the non-Buddhists also has no substance, understanding it in this way is just like this.
I now establish the emptiness of dharmas as the cause to reveal to you, this also establishes the meaning of the absence of a self in persons.
Why is this?
This absence of a self in persons is inseparable from the emptiness of dharmas.
In this way, this cause causes people to believe and understand.
It is like the one who establishes the proposition that sound is impermanent.
How does one state the reason?
It is said to be because it is produced.
As for being produced, suffering, emptiness, and non-self can also be established.
In this way, establishing the non-existence of dharmas establishes the meaning of the non-self of persons, because they are not separate. As the opponent says.
The meaning of false clarifies that the self-nature of dharmas does not abide.
Now, I answer this meaning.
If a dharma can be grasped, the verse says:
Their substance does not change, and the rest also do not change;
Just as youth does not become old, and old age also does not become youth.
The commentary says:
These two analogies correspond in sequence to the number.
Here, a logical argument is established: the self-nature of dharmas abiding is not reasonable.
Why is it so?
Because it does not abandon its self-nature, like youth and old age.
If it is said that the previous moment of the characteristic of change abiding in old age is called change, this is also unreasonable.
Why is it so?
Because the characteristic of change has already passed, like old age.
If an outsider says that like milk does not abandon its own nature but transforms into curd, therefore the reason is not one-sided, this is not so.
Now I will ask you:
What is curd?
They say milk is.
If milk is curd, not abandoning its own nature, how can it be distinguished as curd?
If it is definitely distinguished, the verse says:
If this substance is the same as different, milk should be curd.
The explanation says:
Because milk does not abandon color, taste, power, function, benefit, etc., milk is not curd.
Difference is also not so.
Why is it so?
As the verse says:
What substance different from milk can produce that curd?
The explanation says:
Because there is no curd to arise, the other substance also has no transformation.
Your statement that the reason is not one-sided is not so.
There are other people who say:
I also do not say milk does not produce curd.
The characteristics of curd are different from milk, yet through the power of combination and mastery, milk produces curd.
The treatise says:
You say the power of combination and mastery, does this milk abandon its own nature and produce curd?
Or does it produce curd without abandoning its own nature?
If so, what is the error?
If it abandons its own nature, then it cannot be said that milk produces curd.
If it does not abandon its own nature, then this contradicts itself.
How does it contradict itself?ğŸ”½If it is milk, how can it be called curd?

This meaning is also refuted as before.
Thus observing, in the ultimate truth, the difference of all dharmas is not established.
Your statement that dharmas have a substance and use this as a reason is an unestablished reason.
The opponent says:
In the ultimate truth, phenomena are not empty.
Why is this?
Because there are phenomena that contradict this, like inverted cognition and non-inverted cognition.
If this were non-existent, then there would be no contradictory phenomena, like space flowers. Because there is contradiction with non-emptiness, therefore emptiness exists.

The treatise states:

As for what you said earlier about the discriminating cause of contradictory dharmas, this cause is not established. It is only to refute attachment that emptiness is provisionally spoken of.
Next, the proponent of the Treatise on the Seventeen Stages says:

As a verse says:
Those who see emptiness
The commentary states:
